body:
I have just realized that I could not find any unit test for `ForecastX`, I am wondering why this was even released? The above example could be used as a start to write unit tests for this composition to make sure its doing what it should do. 
@fkiraly i think you wrote that composition? Why is there no unit test or am I missing sth?

> Why is there no unit test or am I missing sth?

There are currently 420 unit tests for `ForecastX` (counting fixture multiplicities):

```python
from sktime.forecasting.compose import ForecastX
from sktime.utils.estimator_checks import check_estimator

res = check_estimator(ForecastX)
len(res)
```

> I am wondering why this was even released?

This is a volunteer driven open source project, so I would advise a more constructive attitude here.

Here's what a constructive attitude could look like:

> The above example could be used as a start to write unit tests for this composition to make sure its doing what it should do.

Suggestion: do this, then try to diagnose the bug.
I fix bugs in code of others (including yours) plenty of times without pointing blame.

We should appreciate contributions of anyone.
If code is buggy, as core developers, we give advice and help making it better.
yes there are generic tests (which is nice) but no test to actually test the logic that this `ForecastX` is aiming to provide.

> yes there are generic tests (which is nice) but no test to actually test the logic that this ForecastX is aiming to provide.

Yes, you are probably right. So, I suggest to proceed with a constructive attitude.
yes, my constructive contribution was to open this issue already ðŸ˜¸ . Are going to work on this?
well, in the future you may want to watch your tone and formulations like "why this was even released"

I think estimators should only be released if the logic is tested at least with minimal custom tests. There is not any custom test for `ForecastX` thats why it might come with a risk for the package reputation if the package gets too buggy due to bugs that could easily be avoided. So I basically still think that this particular estimator should not have been released without some custom tests. This particular bug is even a quite tricky bug as its a silent bug and only advanced users might be able to identify it.
here's what would be a huge help, @aiwalter: go through the package and write logic/consistency tests for all estimators that don't have any. That would be great.

Sure, actually `ForecastX` is the first one I have seen that does not have any custom test. I already fixed one bug in `Imputer`, but due to "there is not enough description in the PR head and missing GitHub tags" it didnt make it to new release. So was not too motivating for me to continue debugging and make PRs.
let's not have this discussion here, this is going off-topic.
so can you let me know if you plan to work on that? Otherwise I might do so, thx a lot!

issue.title: [BUG] fix `ForecastX` predictions

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3986 and includes consistency tests.

The reason for the bug is that columns may end up permuted, and the wrapped forecaster may or may not be able to cope with that. The fix is ensuring that the `X` in predict always has columns in the same order as in `fit`.

Probably, we should ensure that all estimators can deal with permuted columns by coercing in the base class, but that's a separate topic.

body: The issue is with the base framework or the base contract, it leaves ambiguous what happens if columns get permuted.

question regading `ForecastX` using in `evaluate`, as mentioned above already. In `evaluate(y=y, X=X, forecaster=ForecastX(..., columns=["A," "B"])` can you verify that the given columns `["A", "B"]` in `X` are overwritten in `predict` with the predictions from `forecaster_X`? Would be great to have a test for that as well if we agree that overwriting should be the desired behavior?

>can you verify that the given columns `["A", "B"]` in `X` are overwritten in `predict` with the predictions from `forecaster_X`?

Yes, I think so - line 1265

> Would be great to have a test for that as well if we agree that overwriting should be the desired behavior?

I know I might be repeating myself here - this is a volunteer driven open source project, so usually the best way to get something you want is to make a PR.

issue.title: [ENH] dealing with permuted columns between `fit` and `predict` - design & how

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Currently, the various `sktime` base classes do not deal directly with a case where (variable) columns of data frames seen in `predict` are permutations of those seen in `fit`. It is left to individual estimators to deal (or not deal) with this case, which can lead to hard to find silent bugs such as the one in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3986.

Examples where this could occur: exogeneous data `X` in forecasting; feature columns in `X` in classification, regression, clustering.
Obviously, we can mitigate the issue *only* if the mtype comes with a column index, i.e., is `pandas` based or a column indexed type (e.g., `dask`, `xarray`).

Questions:
* should we add functionality in the base class for this?
* or, instead, should we add a test?
* if we add functionality in the base class, it seems it would be mtype specific, as we can do this only for the column indexed mtypes. Would that require dispatch functionality for all the mtypes? Seems hairy.
* If we add a test, what would the test look like? Would it live in the estimator contract test suite?
